Moli now hopes for a loan to buy more fish for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who also have small businesses.The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more fish for her business.

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en: Madam Hawa B. was overwhelmed with joy with her last loan from Kiva. Her family depends solely on her income.  She is grateful that her profits increased and during the loan period she was able to meet her family’s basic needs. She completed paying her installments in March and is requesting another of loan to expand her business.

loans.use: Increase her stock

loans.name: Sok

texts.en: Mrs. Sok K. lives in Pon Ley Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. She is a perfume seller. Mrs. Sok K. is a widow whose child is a driver. So in this family has only two members and they are in poor condition even though they have different business activities. Mrs. Sok K. and her child live in an old house where the roof is always leaking during rainy season. In order to fix the roof, Mrs. Sok K. decided to ask for a loan to fix it.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to fix the roof of the house.

loans.name: Marvin Alexis

texts.es:
Hello, my name is Marvin O. and I run a small internet cafe, offering international calling and photocopying services as well.  I’ve run the business for over one year and my clientele is great.  They love the speed of the internet and the clarity of the long-distance phone calls.  My wife helps me attend to the customers while also caring for our children as we run the cafe out of our home.  

Currently, my business is growing and I need to buy more computers and other supplies to attend to our customers better and meet their demands.  This is why I am seeking a loan in order to move forward with my business and my family. 

 Translated from Spanish by Scott Crandall, Kiva Volunteer.

hola mi nombre es Marvin O. me dedico a prestar el servicio de internet, llamadas al exterior y fotocopiado, tengo mi negocio hace 1 año, mi clientela es muy buena ya que les gusta la velocidad del internet y que las llamadas telefonicas se escucha bien claro, tengo la ayuda de mi esposa para la atencion de los clientes asi no descuidamos a nuestros hijos ya que ella pasa permanente en la casa y nuesto negocio queda en nuestra casa de habitacion, en estos momentos mi negocio esta creciendo y necesito comprar mas computadoras y otros suministros para poder atender a mis clientes de una mejor forma y poder cubrir con las necesidades de ellos por tal razon estoy solicitando ayuda crediticia para poder salir adelante con mi negocio y mi familia.

loans.use: Purchase of two computers and computer supplies

loans.name: Rahmatullo.

texts.ru:
Rahmatullo N. lives in the area of Abdurahmon Jomi, and is involved in agriculture. He owns a piece of land on which he sows wheat, flax and other grains. The second growing season is about to arrive, and it is vital to ready the land for the seeds. Therefore Rahmatullo plans to take out a loan so that he can buy seed and fertilizer. He then sells the crop at the market. He is 46 years old, married and has six children. He also works on a construction site, which helps him feed his family. He plans to repay the loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Maria Lyuksyutova, Kiva volunteer.

Назаров Рахматулло житель района Абдурахмони Джоми . Занимается земледелием. Имеет участок земли . Сеет пшеницу , лен и различные кльтуры. Наступает сезон повторного посева , поэтому необходимо подготовить землю и семена. Поэтому он планирует получить кредит для того , чтобы закупить семена и удобрения. Получаемый урожай реализует на рынке. Возраст 46 лет , Женат и имеет шестерых детей. Кроме земледелия работает на стройке, что позволяет прокормить семью. Погасить кредит планирует в течение 12 месяцев.

loans.use: Purchase of seed and fertilizer.

loans.name: Komlan

texts.fr:
Monsieur A. Komlan est tailleur. Il est âgé de 47 ans, est marié et père de 3 enfants. Il exerce son activité depuis 1989. Bientôt c’est la rentrée scolaire. Il sera sollicité pour la confection des uniformes scolaires. Etant donné qu’il vend aussi des articles de merceries, la demande va croître. Son activité ne consiste pas seulement à confectionner des habits pour vendre mais aussi former les jeunes qui veulent bien évoluer dans ce domaine très passionné.
Il aura à cet effet besoin de ce crédit pour l’achat des articles de merceries et de tissus.
texts.en:
Mr. Komlan A. is a tailor. He is 47 years old, married, and has 3 children. He has run his business since 1989. Soon the school year will start and he will be asked to make school uniforms. Given that he also sells haberdashery items, the demand for his goods will increase. His business does not consist only of making ready-to-wear clothes, but also includes training youths who are very passionate and want to develop their skills in this field. He is therefore in need of this loan to buy haberdashery items and fabrics.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fabric and haberdashery items

loans.name: Elena

texts.es:
Elena C. D. M. tiene domicilio propio en la zona Las Delicias, su esposo es el señor Emilio M., la pareja tiene dos hijos.
El matrimonio atienD. una pensión (restaurante donD. los clientes que lo deseen pueden comprar una especie D. membresía y almorzar durante un período D. tiempo determinado) en la que sirven almuerzos. Los  ingresos D. este negocio les permitieron comprar su vivienda y construir dos plantas D. estructuras D. su vivienda.
El crédito solicitado será destinado a la conclusión D. la obra fina en dos habitaciones.
Esta es la quinta vez que Elena solicita préstamo, el análisis socioeconómico realizado la califica favorablemente y pueD. acceder  a un  crédito.
texts.en:
Elena C. D. M. has her own home in the Las Delicias zone. Her husband is named Emilio, and the pair has two children.

The couple tends to a pension (a restaurant where customers can purchase a type of membership and eat lunch there for a determined period of time) where they serve lunch. The income from this business allowed them to buy their house, as well as to build two additions to it.

The loan sought would be destined to complete the detail work on two bedrooms.

This is the fifth time that Elena solicits a loan, and the financial analysis conducted indicates that she qualifies favorably for access to credit.


Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Construction.

loans.name: Joaquina

texts.es:
La señora Joaquina Espínola es de la ciudad de San Estanislao, tiene 29 años de edad, y está casada con el señor Mario Acosta de 31 años de edad.

Comenzó a montar su pequeña despensa hace 6 años, ya que anteriormente era vendedora ambulante, luego tuvo problemas de salud, y se dejó de ese trabajo.

Gracias a los créditos que recibió de la Fundación Paraguaya, la Sra. Joaquina, pudo comprar las mercaderías para su despensa.

Logrando así un mayor ingreso en sus ventas, por la creciente clientela. Ella comercializa todo tipo de comestibles y artículos de primera necesidad como: azúcar, leche, huevos, frutas, verduras, carne, pan, enlatados, harina, entre otros.

Desea adquirir este crédito para poder reforzar su stock de mercaderías, especialmente con bebidas ya que el calor en esta época hace que la demanda de gaseosas, cervezas, jugos entre otros aumente con mayor consideración.
texts.en:
Mrs. Joaquina E. is from the city of San Estanislao, is 29 years old, and is married with MR. Mario Acosta, who is 31.

She started to run her small business six years ago, since before that she was a traveling vendor and after having health problems, she stopped that work.

Thanks to the loans that she received from the Paraguayan Foundation, Mrs. Joaquina was able to buy the merchandise for her store.

She has achieved a better income because of her growing clientele. She sells all types of groceries and necessary goods, like: sugar, milk, eggs, fruit, vegetables, meat, bread, flour and others.

She hopes to acquire this loan to be able to reinforce her stock, especially with drinks now that the heat in this season makes the demand for soda, beer, juices and other drinks grow.

Translated from Spanish by Zach Frey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying merchandise

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a sewing machine and additional fabric.

loans.name: Jug Maya

texts.en:
Mrs. Jug Maya M. is a 49-year-old lady who lives in Thecho, Lalitpur District, Nepal. She lives in with her husband, son, and daughter. Both her son and daughter are studying in the post-secondary BBS level.

Mrs. M. and her husband, Mr. Govinda M., opened their grocery shop 10 years ago when he was out of work. They sell different types of grocery goods in their shop including rice, maize, pulses, noodles, and biscuits. Their children also help them in their work. All the needs of the family are met by the income of the shop. Mrs. M. is requesting a second loan of NPR 25000 (US$350.00) from Kiva to buy inventory for her shop.

loans.use: To buy grocery inventory

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace V. lives in Barangay Yeban Sur in Benito Soliven, Isabela. She is already a widow and was left with three children: Mark Anthony– 15 years old, third year in high school; Mark Kevin– 13 years old, first year in high school; and Mary Ann– six years old, an elementary student.  

She solely took all the responsibilities in making a living for her family. Grace is just thankful that she had already established her sari-sari store (community based store) before her husband died. Through her business, she was able to send her children to school and provide for the immediate needs of her family.

Grace hopes for progress with her small business so that she can support the needs of her family. At present, she is asking for financial assistance from the lenders amounting to PHP 12,000 to purchase more stock for her store. She also intends to use some of the loan for their farming needs.  

According to Grace, committing everything to the Lord is not enough; it should be accompanied with good works, patience, perseverance, and faith to become successful. Grace is praying that her children will someday finish their studies and have a decent jobs in the future.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock for her store

loans.name: Upendo S.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! Pictured here is 29 year-old Upendo I. from Mbeya. She is married with two children who are between the ages of seven and 12. Upendo has been running a clothes shop since 2007. 

She works at the business for nine to 12 hours per day, six days per week and is assisted by her husband. Upendo currently earns about 150 USD a month from her business. 

She is requesting a loan of 525 USD in order to purchase more clothes in bulk. In the future, she plans to increase more clothes for reselling. Upendo thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA:
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventories of clothing for her business

loans.name: Tina

texts.en: Tina is 45 years old and married with 5 children. She sells provisions, drinks and foodstuffs. She hopes to expand this business. She hopes for a loan in the amount of N120,000 to purchase more provisions, drinks and foodstuffs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions, drinks and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Oluwatoyin

texts.en: Oluwatoyin is 35 years old and married with two children. She lives in Lagos State, Nigeria. O. sells sarongs and the demand for her sarongs is high. She wants a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more sarongs to sell. She says thanks to all that made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Faasavali

texts.en:
Faasavali T., 45, is married with 3 children. She has many years of experience in the vegetable garden and the shop business. She sells to the general public 7 days per week. She has 4 previous loans with SPBD, Kiva's partner. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala (~208 USD).

SPBD loans are Faasavali’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her loan will be used on her businesses only.

loans.use: Purchase wheelbarrow, seeds, fertilizer, snack foods, tinned foods and frozen foods

loans.name: Abena

texts.en:
Abena N., 50, is married and lives with her husband and four children (two sons and two daughters) in a rented apartment in a farming/commercial town called Takorase, near Akim Oda in the Eastern Region of Ghana. While few of her children are in the junior high school others are in the senior high school. Abena works to support her husband financially to provide for the family and especially meet the children’s school demands. Her husband is a farmer while she is a trader. 

She buys foodstuffs such as maize, yam, plantain, rice and vegetables from nearby smaller communities and sells to food vendors and retailers in her community. Abena has been in business for two years and wants a loan to procure goods in bulk to expand her business. She hopes to expand her business and give her children the best of education.

loans.use: To buy foodstuffs to expand business

loans.name: Georgina

texts.en:
Georgina N. was born 39 years ago. She is married and mother of two kids. Currently her kids are in school. Georgina runs a cold store and has sold frozen foods like chicken, mutton, fish, meat, sausages, etc. in the local market of Mankessim for seven years now. Georgina also sells wooden boards for chopping of vegetables.
 
Working for the past seven years, her small working capital has mostly limited her business progress. With the loan, she wants to purchase an additional deep freezer and cartons of frozen foods like fish, chicken and meat to enable her improve her sales. She is expecting to increase her profit margin and save toward business expansion and also provide support for kids education. She would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To purchase  frozen foods like fish, chicken and mutton.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth C. is from the city of Dapitan. She is 51 years old, married mother of six school-aged children. To make a living, Elizabeth owns and operates a manufacturing business. The main source of income for the business comes from manufacturing and selling products, especially curtains to local businesses and community members. Elizabeth has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month.

In 2008, Elizabeth joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to improve her living situation and to engage in business activities. Elizabeth has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC to purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products.

Elizabeth is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP to purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Elizabeth from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

--------------------------------------- About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: Purchase raw materials to manufacture products.

loans.name: Régine

texts.fr: Régine E. est une femme de 38 ans, mariée et mère de 2 enfants. elle est revendeuse de jus de fruits et tient aussi le commerce des cartes de recharge. Elle désire avec ce crédit acroître la taille de son commerce surtout celui des cartes de recharge dont elle veut faire des livraisons en gros. Elle compte sur cette aubaine pour améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Régine E. is a 38-year-old woman, married, and the mother of two. She is a retailer of fruit juices and also runs a business selling mobile phone recharge cards. She would like to use this loan to expand her business, especially in recharge cards, which she wants to deliver in bulk. She is counting on this great opportunity to improve her family’s living conditions.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy recharge cards for resale

loans.name: Phol

texts.en:
Phol S., 35, is a hairdresser with a typical income of US$ 3.50 per day. She is married and has two school-aged children. Until recently she was involved in a business of hairdressing at the market, and her husband and S. decided to buy the business, however, the market is closed now.

She really wants to take out a loan of US$ 1200 to purchase another shop at a market where she thinks there will be many customers who will come to her shop for make-up and hairdressing. She really hopes that her skills and experience in her current business will help her to earn more income not only to support her children’s studies but also to repair her house. (S. in the red shirt is shown in the picture)

loans.use: To buy a hairdressing shop.

loans.name: Saphina

texts.en:
Saphina is a member of the Sokoni borrower group in Kola, Morogoro. She is a 40-year-old woman, is separated from her husband, and is the mother of four children aged 25, 23, 21 and 14 years.
 
Four years ago, Saphina started her own food business selling vegetables. She works twelve hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 60,000 Tanzania Shillings.

This is Saphina’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 350,000 Tsh in order to buy more vegetables. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, she hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more tomatoes, bananas and potatoes

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is 38 years old and the mother of seven children.  She is married to Beterciano who works as a welder and also drives a tricycle taxi. Their family lives in the village of San Ignacio, Ilagan, Isabela. With the earnings from their small business, she hopes their children will be able to complete their studies. 

Josephine is requesting a loan of PHP 5,000 to purchase materials needed to maintain their tricycle. She hopes to obtain the loan because it will help them continue to provide transportation services in their village. The earnings from the business are used for the education of their children and she is hoping to provide them a higher level of education to uplift their lives for the better.

loans.use: To maintain their tricycle taxi.

loans.name: Ricardo

texts.es:
EL Sr. Ricardo M. tiene 68 años de edad, esta casado hace varios años con la Sra. Rosalina, tienen tres hijos, todos mayores de edad e independientes.
El Sr. M. junto con su Sra. trabajan hace más de 20 años a la compra venta de carbón, esta actividad lo han hecho desde que sus hijos eran pequeños, se inicio con un pequeño capital y actualmente posee un móvil con la cual realiza la entrega de sus mercaderías a despensas, copetines y kioscos del barrio.
Solicita su préstamo para la compra de carbón al por mayor.

loans.use: compra de carbón en grandes cantidades

loans.name: Road To Success Group

texts.en:
Osman K. and Mohamed K. are small scale businessmen in Makeni city. They sell used clothes and have been in this business for more than 20 years now. Business had been growing at a very slow pace for these entrepreneurs, but thanks to SMT/Kiva loans, they are now experiencing vast improvements in both their business and personal lives. Previously, each one of them received a loan of Le 800,000.00. Having repaid those fully, they are now each asking for a new loan of Le 1,000,000 to further strengthen their businesses.

Osman K., shown on the left in the photo, is the leader of this group. Born in the village of Ruchain Malal in the Tokolili district of northern Sierra Leone, he is 45, married, and the father of five children. With this loan, Osman will be able to buy at most two bales of used clothes.

loans.use: Invest in his business

loans.name: Abel De Jesus

texts.es: El Joven Abel de Jesús R. M., tiene la edad de 24 años, habita en la Francia N0 1, junto a su esposa la cual trabaja como comerciante para apoyarle con los gastos del hogar, ellos tiene un bebe de un mes de vida, los planes hacia su familia es terminar de construir su casa, el joven desde hace siete años trabaja como agricultor, gracias al apoyo de su papá logro establecer piña y pitahaya. Agradece a la institución por el apoyo y la asistencia técnica ya que con el primer desembolso obtuvo una buena producción la cual vendió a un mejor precio y logro pagar en tiempo y forma. Con este  financiamiento comprara fertilizantes y seguir adelante dándole un mejor cuidado y fertilizando para una buena cosecha sin afectación de plaga.

loans.use: Comprar fertilizantes y mejorar la produccion

loans.name: Mansita

texts.fr: Mansita K., est une femme de 53 ans, elle est mariée et coépouse (2ème femme) elle a 5 enfants et membre du Banc Villageois de "SAMBA 15ANS2" depuis 3 ans. Avec son crédit elle achète des rouleaux de tissu et des bobines de fils pour confectionner et vendre des draps de lit, elle fabrique aussi artisanalement de l'encens elle exporte vers les pays étrangers. Elle contribue beaucoup au bien-être de sa famille.
texts.en:
Mansita K. is a 53-year-old woman.  She is married and is a co-spouse (the second wife).  She has five children and has been a member of Banc Villageois de "SAMBA 15ANS 2" for three years.  With her current loan, she buys rolls of cloth and spools of thread to make bedsheets to sell. She also makes incense by hand that she exports to foreign countries.  She does a lot to help her family's well-being. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To further her business

loans.name: Apu Salkantay Group

texts.es:
Nuestros socios, pertenecen al banco comunal “APU SALKANTAY”, es el nombre de una montaña sagrada de la cordillera de Vilcabamba, y está ubicado al sur de la Ciudadela Sagrada de Machu Picchu, en la ciudad del Cusco. Nuestros miembros son 10 socios, todos ellos son muy amigables y emprendedores. Los socios viven en la ciudad del Cusco, la mayoría de ellos son comerciantes independientes y tienen actividades similares.   

Nuestros socios alternan sus diversas actividades con el comercio minorista. Ellos tienen diferentes negocios como venta de ropa, productos de belleza. Una de las socias su trabajo es el arte culinario, ella hace mesecillos, bizcochuelos, etc. Otra socia es enfermera y hace servicio a domicilio de rehabilitación, a niños autistas, parapléjicos. etc. La mayoría de las socios se dedica a comprar y vender madera, compran de la ciudad de “Puerto Maldonado” y lo distribuyen a pequeñas carpinterías en la ciudad del Cusco de otro socio su trabajo laboral es de transportar la madera de ciudad a ciudad.           


Todos los miembros del banco comunal son nuevos socios y están deseosos de invertir el préstamo en sus nuevos negocios y de este modo hacerlos crecer, esto ayudará a mejorar la calidad de vida de sus hogares y les dará mayor producción y mayor ganancia.

Los socios valoran y agradecen el préstamo otorgado mediante este medio y así mismo se comprometen a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.

(El socio CESAR no esta en la foto por que estaba de viaje estaba trabajando como guía de turistas,  en el “Valle sagrado de los Inkas”)
texts.en:
Our members belong to the communal bank “APU SALKANTAY”, which is the name of a sacred mountain in the Vilcabamba mountain range. It is located south of Ciudadela Sagrada of Machu Picchu, in Cusco. There are ten members in the bank and they are all very friendly and entrepreneurial. They live in the city of Cusco. The majority of the members are independent retailers and have similar businesses.
Our members alternate between retail businesses. They have different businesses, such as, selling clothes and beauty products. One of the members is a cook and she makes traditional pastries (mesecillos, bizcochuelos). Another member is a nurse and provides home therapy visits to handicap and autistic kids. Most of the members buy and sell lumber. They buy in the city of “Puerto Maldonado” and sell to small woodshops in the city of Cusco. Another member transports the wood across the different cities.
All the members of the communal bank are new and are looking forward to invest the loan in growing their businesses. This loan will help them improve the quality of life at home and will provide better production and profits. The members are very thankful for the loan they will obtain through Kiva and are committed to repaying the loan within the established terms.
(The member CESAR is not in the picture because he was away working as a tourist guide at the “Valle sagrado de los Inkas”)

Translated from Spanish by Rina Paguaga, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and sell lumber and beauty products.

loans.name: Neminda

texts.en:
Neminda M. is from the village of Lower Dicayas. She is 53 years old. Neminda is married and has one adult child. To make a living, Neminda owns and operates a food stall. The main source of income for the business comes from selling ground beef and pork products known as "longganisa" in the local community. Neminda has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Neminda joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Neminda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Neminda is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used for the same purpose. This will be the 7th loan taken out by Neminda from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Luz En Desarrollo 1 & 2 Group

texts.en:
Joaquina, 50, is a borrower who lives in Los Alcarrizos, Dominican Republic. She is the coordinator for her group, Luz en Desarrollo (Developing Light), and her story is representative of the other borrowers in the group.

Joaquina has a small business selling home decorations to her friends and the people in her neighborhood. With this loan, her very first with Esperanza International, she will be purchasing Christmas decorations to sell at a small markup. She also buys fabrics, bathroom decorations, and other types of interior decorations to sell to her customers. In addition to buying more inventory, Joaquina will purchase a new fan for her business so that it is more comfortable for her customers.

Joaquina, her husband, and her children live in a difficult area. Los Alcarrizos can be a tough place to live with no potable running water, little access to electricity, and poor sanitation. Despite those difficulties, Joaquina is optimistic for the future. She believes that with the support of extra business profits, her children will now be able to do whatever they would like with their lives. Joaquina also would like to continue expanding her business, buying equipment and moving to a larger store. Thank you for your loan to Joaquina and the Luz en Desarrollo group!

loans.use: to buy Christmas decorations to sell

loans.name: Deisi Beatriz

texts.es: Deisi Beatriz L. D. J. D. 32 años D. edad, resiD. en el departamento D. Ahuachapán junto a su esposo y sus dos hijos. Ella posee una venta D. ropa deportiva para hombres y mujeres, así mismo venD. ropa casual. Deisi solicita un préstamo a través del cual desea poder comprar pantalones, blusas, camisas y falda D. diferentes estilos y colores. Ella desea mucho poder aumentar sus ventas ya que desea poder brindarle mayor ayuda a su esposo con todos los gastos del hogar y D. esta manera poder darles una mayor estabilidad económica a su familia.
texts.en:
Deisi Beatriz is 32 years old and lives in Ahuachapán, along with her husband and two children. She sells men’s and women’s sports attire, as well as casual clothing. Deisi is requesting this loan so that she can invest in pants, blouses, shirts, and skirts of various styles and colors. She would really like to increase her sales and be able to help her husband more with the household expenses and be able to give her family more economic stability.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy clothing for resale

loans.name: Twaha

texts.en:
M. Twaha is a businessman, 46 years old, and the father of five kids. He has a metal workshop in Abaita Ababiri Trading Centre. He started his business five years back.

Twaha is using the loan to purchase metal materials for making metal doors, windows, tanks, and so on, to expand his business. His aim is to expand his house and educate his children.

loans.use: To purchase metal materials for his business

loans.name: Las Originales Group

texts.es: Las originales está conformado por tres mujeres trabajadoras ellas son Juana O. la cual desde hace años vende zapatos, Deyanira H. que tiene un taller de costura y Darling Yesenia S. vende cosméticos.
texts.en:
The "Originales" group is made up of three hard-working women: Juana Orodoñez has sold shoes for several years, Deyanira Hernándz has a sewing business, and Darling Yesenia S. sells cosmetics.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase shoes to sell

loans.name: Divine

texts.en: Divine is a tailor and she makes lovely Nigerian and Western designs for her customers. She also sells clothes. With these businesses she hopes to meet the basic needs of her family. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She hopes for the loan amount of NGN 120,000 to purchase more clothes and tailoring materials. She is married with 5 children and her husband is a businessman who also supports the household. She hopes to own a big fashionable home in the future. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes and tailoring materials

loans.name: Abdykalykova Kanayim`s Group

texts.en: Kanayim, 50, is married with 6 children. Her 3 oldest children are in Russia, while the other 3 go to school. Her husband works in the family business. They fatten cattle which they sell in the local market. She also sells milk and milk products and has been in this business since she got married. The average family income is about 350 USD. This loan will be used to buy 2 calves to fatten. Taalay is 47 years old and is married with 4 children. They have 2 main sources of income: trade and livestock. His wife works in her own little shop where she sells food and consumer loans. Taalay also fattens animals. This loan will be used to buy 1 milk cow with a calf. It will also let them produce milk and milk products to sell. Gulmayram is 39 years old. She is married with 4 children. Her husband is a taxi driver. All her children are at university or school. She has been working in the livestock business since 1992 and her annual income is about 200 USD. This loan will be used to buy 1 milk cow with a calf. She hopes that this will increase her income and that she will be able to repair her house this year. Guljan is married. Her husband is currently in Russia. She has 2 grown children: a son and a daughter. She is in the livestock business and has 3 cows and 3 sheep. She will use this loan to buy 3 more sheep. In the near future she wants to open a mini-market near her house to diversify her sources of income. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious, socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of both its customers and the society), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and to view a video presentation about the organization, please click here If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: to buy 2 calves

loans.name: John

texts.en: John is a 36-year-old married man with three children. He is a hardworking man who sells DVDs and CDs as well as videocassettes.  He has been in this business for fifteen years. For more profit, he also sells spare parts and provides transport services. He has been able to improve his business through Faulu Kenya. This is because he was previously hawking radio cassettes and videotapes. He has requested for a loan of KES 80,000 to add stock of tyres, windscreens, suspension and paint.  He hopes to get a better market for his products and to open a music shop. He sees himself buying a plot and building a family house in the future.

loans.use: Add inventory for his shop.

loans.name: Mercy Grace

texts.en: Mercy Grace L. is from the village of Dabong-dabong, Mailag Valencia City, Bukidnon. She is 31 years old. Mercy Grace is single and has an infant child. To make a living, Mercy Grace owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Mercy Grace has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 4,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2009, Mercy Grace joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mercy Grace has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. Mercy Grace is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the thirrd loan taken out by Mercy Grace from HSPFI, a Kiva partner. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Musi

texts.en:
Born in 1955, Musi E. is married with seven children and she is unemployed. Although she attributes her unemployment to her low education, she is appreciative of the fact that she is alive. Her desire is to give her children love and education. She states that she feels better each time she provides something small for her kids.

E.’s inability to obtain investment capital which could constantly generate income for her to meet her children’s needs, is what motivated her to obtain a loan from GHAPE. With her previous loans, she succeeded in providing her community with foodstuffs from her farm and puff puff (Cameroon-style doughnuts). She has taken and repaid loans twice from GHAPE.

Given the loan, E. plans to buy flour, onions, tomatoes, palm oil and seedlings. This investment will increase the food supply in the community. She is planning to use the profits generated to sponsor her children in school and to cater to the basic needs of her family.

Elizaberth’s loan would be provided through the Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE), a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To buy more flour, onions, tomatoes, palm oil and seedlings

loans.name: Cueto Group

texts.es:
El grupo el Cueto está integrado por tres personas trabajadoras una de ellas son Mercedes Ángeles P. Gonzales propietaria de una pequeña  pulpería la cual inicio con poca mercadería la cual por medio el tiempo fue mejorando.
Sus compañeras de grupo son Luz Adilia S. Hernández quien tiene un bar y cafetín  desde hace 11 años y Juan Francisco Gutierres S. propietario de un taller de recarga de baterías de carro.  Ellos invertirán en sus respectivos negocios.
texts.en:
The 'Cueto' group is made up of three hard working people. One of them is Mercedes Ángeles P. Gonzales, the owner of a small general store which began with little merchandise and grew over time. Her fellow group members are Luz Adilia S. Hernández, who has had a bar and a kiosk for the last eleven years, and Juan Francisco Gutierres S., who owns a workshop of rechargable car batteries. They will invest their loan in their respective businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Suzanne Grasso, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of legumes, meat, soft drinks and dairy products.

loans.name: Cecilio

texts.es:
El señor Cecilio D. L. y la señora Ofelia Grimaldo tiene dos hijos ha quienes les quieren dar lo mejor.
En este momento la familia esta posando por un mal momento, la señora Ofelia Grimaldo esta enferma y necesita unos estudios medico, pero no cuenta con el dinero necesario para que se pueda realizar los exámenes médicos que necesita.
Es por eso que están solicitando un préstamo y así poder pagar a la clínica que se encargara D. los estudios médicos.   
Planean pagar el crédito con el ingreso que obtiene D. su taller D. reparación D. autos.
texts.en:
Mr. Cecilio D. L. and Mrs. Ofelia Grimaldo have two children and they wish to give them the best. Currently, the family is going through bad times. Mrs. Ofelia Grimaldo is sick and needs some medical exams but she does not have the money needed to have the tests that she needs.

This is why they need he loan, to be able to pay the clinic that will be in charge of the medical tests.

They plan to pay the loan with the income that that they get from their automobile mechanic workshop.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Duque, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Medical expenses.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 20-year-old single man from Lebanon. He has been working as a farmer since 2005 and he has over 7 years of experience in the agricultural industry. He lives with his parents and two siblings. Both he and one parent work to support the household.

He is requesting a loan from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to buy supplies for his farm such as fertilizer. He is requesting a loan of US$ 2000. This will be his second Kiva loan. 

Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e., blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, not indicating his/her name and location, etc.) Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.

Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loan from Kiva lenders to offer lower interest loans with faster disbursement for their micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling US $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit: http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115

loans.use: to buy supplies for his farm such as fertilizer

loans.name: Leonardo Jaime

texts.es:
Leonardo Jaime thornè D. 37 años vive con su cónyuge y  2 hijos D. 4 y 6 años D. edad, en el Municipio D. Malambo, área metropolitana D. BarranquilL., y tiene el negocio D. vender agua purificada y frigoríficos que él mismo procesa, además D. otro donD. alquiL. lavadoras. Leonardo quiere comprar  una carretilL. para L. moto, para facilitar el transporte  D. sus tanques D. agua y necesita tambien adquirirá mas tanques para ampliar sus posibilidades D. mercado; esta es L. razon  por lo cual está aplicando a un crédito por valor D. $1.000.000 COP.
Leonardo es auxiliar contable y trabajó durante 6 años con el estado en el municipio D. Malambo, pero hace 2 años quedó sin empleo y con su liquidación comenzó a vender carnes frías , luego se dio cuenta que el servicio D. alquiler D. lavadoras era una buena alternativa y compró sus primeras 2 lavadoras y cuando hace un año, a través D. L. Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, conoció a un microempresario que venD. agua purificada, comenzó como su vendedor y este finalmente al ver su capacidad emprendedora, le recomendó a esta organización, donD. solicitó su primer crédito, con el que compró su propia planta purificadora con tres filtros D. ozono y 1 tanque D. almacenamiento, en L. actualidad esta es L. actividad que más ingreso le genera, pero tiene L. dificultad para transportar distribuir el agua y ha recurrido a su hermana para que le facilite L. moto con carretilL. adjunta, para cumplir con los pedidos. Leonardo dice que su vida ha cambiado desD. que recibió su primer crédito conL. Fundación, porque logró independizarse y han mejorado notablemente sus ingresos familiares. Sueña con tener una vivienda propia y fortalecer el negocio mejorando su infraestructura e incrementando su clienteL.. Su desafío inicial fuè cuando perdió su empleo, pero esto lo llevó a desarrollar su potencial emprendedor y en este momento las condiciones son otras, aunque aún como no tiene casa propia L. purificadora L. tiene en L. casa D. su madre. Leonardo se siente muy conternto porque en Malambo este es un buen negocio porque L. percepción D. los ciudadanos D. que su agua no es potable, los lleva a buscar el negocio D. Leonardo como una buena alternativa D. consumo D. agua pura.
texts.en:
Leonardo Jaime T., 37, lives with his partner and their 2 children, 4- and 6-years old, in the Malambo neighborhood of BarranquilL.. He operates a business selling cold, purified water that he processes himself. He also has a second business renting washing machines. Leonardo wants to buy a trailer for his motorcycle so that he can more easily carry tanks of water and he needs to buy more tanks so that he can expand his water business. That´s why he´s applying for a COP$1,000,000 loan. Leonardo is a bookkeeper and he worked for the state in Malambo for 6 years before he was laid off 2 years ago. He used his severance pay to start a business selling cold meats. He then hit on the idea of renting washing machines, a business for which he bought two machines. A year ago, the Fundacion Mario Santo Domingo matched him with a microbusiness selling purified water. He started working for the business as a salesman. When he saw the potential for the business, he applied to the Fundacion for a loan so that he could start his own business. He bought a water purifier with three filters and 1 storage tank and the business now generates more than his other. The problem is that he can´t easily carry the water so he has asked his sister to help him by riding along in a sidecar for deliveries. Leonardo says that his life has changed since he received his first Fundacion loan because it´s allowed him to set up his own business and increased his income. Losing his job was a challenge, but it has allowed him to develop his potential as an entrepreneur. Since he doesn´t have a house of his own, he operates the business at his mother´s house. Leonardo is very happy with the business because he can sell safe water to the people of Malambo where the feeling is that the water is not safe.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy trailer for transporting water for water business.

loans.name: The Lord Is King Group

texts.en:
Boakai S., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called 'The Lord Is King'. He is 35 years old, married, and has two children, 3 and 6 years old. He was only able to attend school through 12th grade due to lack of support.
  
For 7 years, he has been selling rice in Redlight Market, on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia.

He plans to use his 6,000 Liberian Dollar portion of this 30,000 Liberian Dollar group loan to buy more bags of rice. His goal is to expand his business and educate his children.

loans.use: To buy more bags of rice.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose A. is currently in the business of selling groundnut paste, bread, tomatoes and cooking oil and is requesting a loan to stock bags of onions and Irish potatoes to sell.  Rose is 29 years old and is married. Her husband is a driver. She has 2 children and her children do not go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house to rent.

loans.use: Stock bags of onions and Irish potatoes to sell

loans.name: Rowena's Group

texts.en:
Rowena O. is from the town of Namillangan Ifugao. She is 35 years old. Rowena is the group leader of a 11-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Rowena O..

Rowena is married and has three school-aged children. Rowena owns and operates a clothing business. The main source of income for the business comes from selling second hand clothes within their village. Rowena has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 2500 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it.

In 2010, Rowena joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. Rowena is requesting a  loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional clothes to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Rowena from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional clothes to sell

loans.name: Isabel

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal  “HATUN SONCCO ”; El banco comunal está ubicado en el distrito de Huanchac, provincia de Cusco y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Isabel,  ella tiene  35  años de edad, es casada con 2 hijos; La socia se dedica  la docencia, ella es profesora de profesión en San Sebastián, ella trabaja con el nivel primaria y también  alterna sus actividades con el hogar, La socia desea  mejorar su casa y también para pagar las mensualidades de sus hijos, para lo cual pide el préstamo, que ella irá pagando poco a poco con su sueldo de profesora.  La socia solicita el préstamo para invertir en los estudios de sus hijos.

La socia agradece y valora el préstamo otorgado mediante este medio y del mismo modo se compromete en cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
This member belongs to the Hatun Soncco communal bank. The bank is located in Huanchac District, Cusco Province and Cusco Department. The member is Isabel. She is 35 years old and married, with two children. She is a teacher in San Sebastián; she works at the elementary level and also alternates her activities with responsibilities at home. She wants to improve her house and make her children's monthly school payments, for which she is requesting the loan that she will pay back little by little with her teacher's salary. Isabel is asking for the loan to invest in her children's education. She is grateful for and values the loan granted through this medium, and she promises to make her payments as scheduled.

Translated from Spanish by Danielle Maxson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To invest in children's education

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou D. is from the village of Lilingayon, Valencia City. She is 28 years-old and married with four school-aged children. To make a living, Marilou owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income comes from selling both food anddaily use products in the local community. Marilou has been engaged in her business for over one year and earns approximately 9,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Marilou joined Kiva partner HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marilou is requesting a first loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Masheruka Siimuka Coffee Growers, Bushenyi Group

texts.en:
Hard-working and enterprise-oriented Gordon M., aged 35, is operating a nursery and primary school in Bwizibwera as its director. This started 6 years ago and his school has since been accessed by many pupils due to their academic set standards. This has seen Gordon earn 500,000 Ugandan shillings as monthly profits on top of his salary.

This loan will help him in the construction of more buildings to accommodate pupils and also allow him to purchase furniture for the school like desks for pupils so as to improve their comfort at school. He is very optimistic to make his school grow into the best institution not only in his region but in Uganda. 

Gordon belongs to Masheruka Siimuka coffee growers’ group of members who insure each other in paying back the loan.

loans.use: contribution towards construction of more school buildings

loans.name: Carmelita

texts.en:
Carmelita A. is from the village of Cabisera 27. She is 52 years old and married with eight school-aged children. To make a living, Carmelita raises pigs to fatten and sell. She has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Carmelita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6000 PHP from ASKI used to invest in expanding the business and is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Carmelita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell

loans.name: Rowena

texts.en:
Rowena F. is from the village of Paglaum Village, Lumbo, Valencia City, Bukidnon. She is 27 years old. Rowena is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Rowena owns & operates a business venture in the services sector providing recycling services. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling scrap, like plastics, empty bottles and other recyclables for local businesses and community members. Rowena has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Rowena joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rowena is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional plastics & other recyclables to sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Rowena from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional plastics & other recyclables to sell

location.town: Paglaum Village, Lumbo, Valencia City, Bukidnon

loans.name: Mer

texts.en:
Mrs. Mer H., 60, is a widow with three sons and two daughters. She lives in a small village outside of Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. 

Mer is a farmer. She grows vegetables and transports them to sell in Phnom Penh market. Her daughter (pictured above) assists her mother in the business.   

Mer is requesting her first loan of US$500. She will use the loan to purchase a trailer to take vegetables to the market.

loans.use: To purchase a trailer to take vegetables to the market.

loans.name: Ma. Jessica

texts.en: Ma. Jessica C. owns and operates a sari-sari (variety retail shop) buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, detergents, junk foods and biscuits, as well as electronic loads of several networks like Smart and Global in her community. She is a 34-year-old single woman from the village of Old Kibawe, Bukidnon. Ma. Jessica has been in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 7,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2010, Ma. Jessica joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Ma. Jessica is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to buy and sell. This will be her first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to buy and sell

loans.name: Doris

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “EL AMANECER”; El banco está ubicado en el distrito de Cusco, perteneciente a la provincia de Cusco y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Gabriela; ella tiene 29 años de edad y es casada; La socia alterna sus actividades diarias con el negocio de compra y venta de ropa, ella vende en forma independiente y lo distribuye a diferentes tiendas de ropa, ella quiere tener una tienda donde pueda vender la ropa. La socia solicita el préstamo para comprar ropa como pantalones, blusas y chompas.

La socia agradece a quienes forman parte de este sueño mediante este medio y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
The member is part of the "EL AMANECER" ("The Dawn") loan group, located in the district of Cusco, in the province of Cusco, department of Cusco.

Gabriela is 29 years old and married. Alongside her daily activities she buys and sells clothing. She sells independently and sells to different clothing stores. She would like to own a shop where to sell clothes. She is requesting a loan to buy clothing such as trousers, blouses and sweaters.

She would like to thank those supporting her dream and is committed to repaying the loan in the agreed terms.

loans.use: The partner requests the loan to buy clothing such as trousers, blouses and sweaters.

loans.name: Razel

texts.en:
Razel A., from the village of Mapuroc San Mateo, is 35 years old, married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Razel has owned and operated a general store selling a variety of products in the local community for over six years, earning approximately 1400 PHP a month.

In 2010, Razel joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Now requesting her loan of 5000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell, she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her store.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Nyamgongor

texts.en:
Nyamgongor B. is 52 years old and lives with her husband and two sons in Zavhan province, Mongolia. Her older son lives separately while her younger son attends a local school. Nyamgongor and her family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic home tent and fence.
Nyamgongor began her meat-selling business in 1995 and since then has gained a lot of experience. She buys livestock and meat in bulk from the countryside and sells it in her town. Her husband helps in her meat business. Nyamgongor is a loyal and hardworking woman. She is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan in order to purchase more meat for her meat-trading business.

loans.use: To purchase more meat for resale

loans.name: Luis

texts.es:
El socio pertenece al banco comunal “MADRES TRABAJADORAS”; El banco está ubicado en el distrito de Cusco, perteneciente a la provincia de Cusco y departamento de Cusco.

El socio es el Sr. Luis; el tiene 29 años de edad y es conviviente y tiene 2 hijos; El socio alterna sus actividades diarias con el negocio de transporte, el socio realiza servicio de taxi, el tiene un carro que trabaja en las diferentes calles del cusco desde las 5:00 a.m hasta las 6:00 p.m, la socia quiere mejorar el servicio de taxi. El  socio solicita el préstamo para el mantenimiento de su carro.

El socio está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en:
This borrower belongs to the "Madres Trabajadoras" [Hard-Working Mothers"] communal bank, which is located in the district, province, and department of Cusco.

This borrower is Mr. Luis.  He is 29 years old, in a common-law marriage, and has two children.  He divides his time between his daily activities and his transportation business.  Luis runs a taxi service.  He has a car and works along the various streets of Cusco from 5:00 a.m. until 6:00 p.m.  He would like to improve his taxi service, so he requested this loan for maintenance on his car.

Mr. Luis is happy to receive this loan and promises to comply with the repayment schedule.

loans.use: for car maintenance

loans.name: Kossivi Agbéményan

texts.fr: Monsieur S. est marié et a un enfant  en charge. Il est âgé de 31 ans. Pour faire face aux besoins de sa  famille, il fait la vente de friperie. Il est né à Lomé et habite à Attiégou. Il a débuté en 2007 cette activité et s’approvisionne en gros  au  marché local de hedzranawoé. Il revend les habits en détail. Il sollicite un prêt pour acheter 2 balles de friperie.
texts.en: Mr S. is married and has one child in care. He is 31 years old. To provide for his family, he sells second-hand clothes. He was born in Lomé and lives now in Attiégou. He began this activity in 2007 and buys his inventory wholesale at the market in Hedzranawoé. Then he retails the clothes. He applies for a loan to buy two bales of used clothing.

loans.use: To buy second-hand clothes

loans.name: Juditha

texts.en:
Juditha C. is from the village of Mambatangan, Manolo Fortich, Bukidnon. She is 43 years old. Juditha is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Juditha owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop.  She sells daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods,  snack foods and  toothpaste in the local community. Juditha has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 15000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Juditha joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Juditha has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. That loan was used to purchase additional inventory & fund working capital. Juditha is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP, which will be used to purchase more products to sell, such as beverages & snack foods. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Juditha from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase products to sell

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Benkadi, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 40 ans, 5 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Sirablekoro, préfecture de Dioïla, Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font le commerce de condiments, de pâte d’arachide, de galettes, d’habillements et d’oignons.                                                                                      
Les femmes du groupe Benkadi sont à leur quatrième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter des condiments, de l’arachide, des céréales, d’habillements et d’oignons.                                                                          
SITAN KALIDI D. compte acheter des sacs d’oignons avec les grossistes des villages environnants presque hebdomadairement. Elle effectue ses ventes quotidiennement au village et au marché de Dioïla, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 16 000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les échéances du prêt, payer les contributions des cérémonies sociales et le reste sera  réinvesti dans son activité de commerce.
texts.en:
The women of the Benkadi group are all married 40 year-olds with five children each.  They all live in traditional extended families in the village of Sirablekoro, in the municipality of Dioïla, in the region of Koulikoro (in the second largest administrative region of the Republic of Mali).
They met through family and friendship links.  The women sell condiments, peanut butter, biscuits, clothes and onions.                                                                                      
The women of the Benkadi group are on their fourth loan which will be used to purchase more of these goods. 
Sitan Kalidi D. aims to purchase bags of onions weekly from the wholesalers of the neighbouring villages. She sells her wares daily from the market at Dioïla, for cash or credit sales to a customer base made up of men and women. She aims to generate an average monthly profit of 16 000 FCFA which will be used to repay the loan, pay for social ceremonies, and the rest will be reinvested in the business.

loans.use: Purchasing onions

loans.name: Abahuzangufu Group

texts.fr: Protais Ntawukwanga est agriculteur du riz dans le secteur de Bugesera, et membre du groupe Abahuzangufu.  Il a 39 ans, il est marie, ne a Rwanda, et il a 3 enfants entre 2 ans et 13 ans.  Un de ses enfants va à l’école, et Protais a fini 3 ans d’école primaire.  Il est membre d’ACB depuis 2010, ce crédit est son 2eme cycle, et il a une bonne histoire de remboursement.  Il va utiliser ce prêt pour l’achat de NPK, urée, et main d’œuvre pour l’agriculture du riz.  Sa strategie pour la croissance de l’affaire est d’améliorer son activité de l’agriculture du riz.  Il voudrait devenir grossiste, payer les frais médicaux, et payer les frais scolaires pour ses enfants.
texts.en: Protais Ntawukwanga is a rice farmer in the Bugesera sector, and a member of the Abahuzangufu group.  He is 39 years old, married, was born in Rwanda, and has 3 children between the ages of 2 and 13.  One of his children goes to school, and Protais finished 3 years of primary school.  He has been a member of ACB since 2010.  This is his second loan and he has a good repayment history.  He is going to use this loan to purchase NPK and urea fertilizers and labor for the rice farming.  His strategy for the growth of his job is to improve his rice farming trade.  He would like to become a wholesaler, pay medical costs, and pay his children's educational costs.

loans.use: to purchase NPK and urea fertilizers and labor

loans.name: Hiba

texts.en:
Hiba is a young woman from Hebron. Hiba lives with her family. The family owns a farm where they raise goats and use their milk in making cheese and other products. 

Hiba took out a loan from FATEN to purchase two goats to add to the ones they already have in order to increase their milk products.

Hiba who is photographed with her brother in the picture here is from Hebron which is famous for agriculture.

loans.use: to enlarge their herd by purchasing two goats.

loans.name: Esperanza Group

texts.es:
Este comité se formó en el Barrio Empalado Ari de la  Ciudad de Caaguazú, la Sra. Ana Beatriz A. participaba de un grupo de mujeres como comisión vecinal y se enteró por medio de las promociones, que la Fundación Paraguaya otorgaba pequeños préstamos para mujeres, y fue así con mucho entusiasmo decidieron  participar del programa, son 21  señoras trabajadoras que quieren seguir progresando.
La sra. Cristina A. se dedica a la venta de verduras en un puesto propio desde hace mucho tiempo, es un trabajo sacrificado pero ella desea superarse y ayudarle a su familia por eso se esfuerza cada día sin tener en cuenta el cansancio o el excesivo sacrificio.
Solicitó el crédito para poder comprar mayor cantidad de verduras de modo que pueda adquirir a costos más bajos y obtener un margen de ganancia más amplio.
texts.en:
This committee was established in Empalado Ari neighborhood, in the city of Caaguazú.  Ana Beatriz A. used to take part in a women's neighborhood committee.  She found out, through Fundación Paraguaya's promotion work, that they awarded small loans to women.  With a lot of enthusiasm, she and her group decided to take part in the program.  The group has 21 hard-working members who would all like to continue making progress.

Cristina A. has been selling vegetables from a stall that she owns for a long time.  It is hard work but she would like to improve herself and help her family.  For this reason, she works hard every day without paying attention to how tired she is or the sacrifices that she is making.

Cristina requested this loan so that she could buy a larger quantity of vegetables.  This will allow her to acquire her products at a lower cost and make a better profit margin.

loans.use: to buy vegetables (onions, tomatoes, cassava, greens, etc.)

loans.name: Mercedes María

texts.es:
En el cantón Rocafuerte se  reúnen cada quince días las socias del Banco Comunal Trabajando Para Un Futuro. Este lugar se lo conoce por sus deliciosos dulces que preparan los lugareños que son reconocidos en todo el país y por la calidez de su gente amable y trabajadora.

En este lugar conocimos a la señora Mercedes, tiene 46 años de edad y mantiene una relación de unión libre de la cual tiene tres hijos, todos ya son mayores de edad y  estudian en universidad. El marido tiene un taller de ebanistería.
 
Es una muy buena ama de casa que para ayudar a su esposo con los gastos del hogar se dedica a la cría de pollos, tiene  una pequeña granja de pollos en su casa hace cuatro años y le ha ido muy bien. Trabaja todos los días, compra los pollos pequeños en una incubadora y después de tres a cuatro meses entrega en varias tiendas de Rocafuerte y también a comerciantes que llegan hasta su casa, sus hijos le ayudan en esta labor.

Este crédito lo va a utilizar para comprar más pollos, medicinas y alimentos para que tengan un buen crecimiento. Lleva tres ciclos en el Banco.
 
Su sueño es que  sus hijos sean buenos profesionales.
texts.en:
In the canton of Rocafuerte, the members of the "Trabajando Para Un Futuro" ["Working for a Future"] communal bank meet every fifteen days. This area is known for the delicious sweets prepared by the inhabitants, which are recognized throughout the country, and for the warmth of its people, who are friendly and hard-working. 

In this place, we meet Mercedes, who is 46 years old and lives with her common-law husband, with whom she has three children. All of her children are grown and study at the university. Her husband has a furniture-making workshop. 

She is a very good homemaker because she helps her husband with the household expenses, by dedicating herself to raising chickens. She has a small chicken-raising operation at her home. She has done this for four years, and it has gone very well for her. She works every day. She buys the chicks from an incubator, and after three or four months, she delivers them to various stores in Rocafuerte and also sells them to commercial buyers who come to her home. Her children help her with this work. 

She will use this loan to buy more chickens, as well as medicines and feed so that they will achieve good growth. She has been with the communal bank for three loan cycles. 
 
Her dream is that her children will become successful professionals.

loans.use: to buy chickens and feed and medicines for them.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane, a 37 year old, is a single-mother of one. She does printing and photocopying to earn a living. With the income from her business, she is able to provide for her seven-year-old child. It has been ten years since she started her business.  

Since she joined Faulu Kenya, Jane has learned how to manage her finances by saving her money. She has grown her business with her previous loans from Faulu Kenya. She has requested for another loan of 50,000 KES to buy paper for printing and photocopying.

loans.use: To buy printing paper.

loans.name: Akouwa Kpatagnon

texts.fr: Femme de 32 ans, Akouwa est mariée et mère d’un enfant, revendeuse de produits cosmétiques et de tissus, elle s’approvisionne à Cotonou. Elle a mis cette activité en place depuis 2009 et maitrise bien  ce qu’elle fait. Ce premier prêt lui servira à acheter beaucoup plus d’articles pour élargir sa clientèle
texts.en: Akouwa is a 32-year old woman, who is married and mother to one child. She retails cosmetics and fabric and gets her supplies in Cotonou. She began this business in 2009 and masters it well. This first loan will enable her to buy a lot more articles so that she can expand her customer base.

loans.use: to buy cosmetics and fabric

loans.name: Olioli

texts.en:
Olioli is 30 years old and married with five children. Olioli owns and operates a business venture planting and harvesting taro for sale.  She has one year of experience in this business. 

Olioli needs a loan of WST $1,000 to purchase sacks fertilizers and gromozones to improve the standard of her business.  She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 300 talas or US $125 per week) to improve/expand her business.

In 2011, Olioli joined SPBD to gain access to financial services.  Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks, because they lack collateral.  This is Olioli's first loan with SPBD.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of fertilizers and gromozones to improve her business

loans.name: Petronila

texts.en:
This is Petronila, 50, a resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Gabriel, a driver, and mother of two children, one of whom is in college, while the other is in elementary school, a dream for most Filipino parents like Petronila, as she herself has been an undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can leave to their children.

Petronila operates a firewood and charcoal retailing business. In the Philippines, many still use the old ways of cooking (on an earthen stove where firewood is used) to save money. Firewood and charcoal is way cheaper than LPG fuel, which in the current market costs as much as Php 600, and a lot of people in the provinces prefer to buy firewood, which is so cheap that it can be bought for Php 20 a bundle. Petronila also earns by selling the firewood to suppliers who buy it in bulk. More people are also switching to firewood which can be foraged or found in the trash. 

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 10,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of wood and charcoal to rebundle and retail to her customers. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Petronila dreams of being able to give both her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She also hopes to have her family and community with her as she continues to serve the Lord Almighty through her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for new stock and products for her business.

loans.name: Emma

texts.en:
Emma has a shop that sells bread, biscuits and snacks. She has had this business for 6 years. Emma is 39 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with four children. 

Emma has been a member of HSPFI since 2009. She requested a loan of 14,000 Philippine pesos to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages. In the future, Emma hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages.

loans.name: Mumtaz's Group

texts.en:
Mumtaz is a 31-year-old lady. She has given birth to five children: three of them are students while the other two are not of school-going age yet. Her husband is a fruit seller by profession. He sells fresh quality seasonal fruits through his shop which is near his home. 

Mumtaz has applied for a loan from Kiva's partner Asasah because her husband wants to improve his business. With this loan, he will buy fresh seasonal fruits that will allow him to offer his customers better quality fruit for more income. He has been operating this business for the past 15 years and Mumtaz is hopeful that an investment will result in good profits from his business and her family’s financial condition will get better. 

Mumtaz is a regular client of Asasah and this is her second loan application. In previous loan years, she has proven herself to be a responsible client by paying her installments on time and by attending every meeting. In the photo, the lady with a book (an Asasah passbook) is Mumtaz.

loans.use: to buy fresh seasonal fruits for selling.

loans.name: Joyce
